They might try to gain similar for- tune for themselves, or they might seek to take a prize away from the target of their jealousy. A villain who envies another individual’s wealth will not be satis- fi ed by fi nding his own riches. To him, victory can be achieved only by stealing or ruining the other person’s valued treasures. Example (Recognition):Fed up with the suc- cesses of a rival group, a party of evil adventurers plots to smear the characters’ good names. Friendship Rather than building affiliations through honest means, villains who are motivated by friendship coerce and abuse others, forcing companionship through fear. Although the friendship that results is not authentic, the villains accept the illusion of camaraderie. Other villains are so desperate to please that they do terrible things to earn the notice of the person they wish to befriend. Of course, these villains seldom realize that their actions just drive that person farther away. Example (Recognition): Eager to secure an apprenticeship with a famous archmage, a young wizard conspires to steal a potent artifact from a vault beneath Boccob’s temple and bestow the gift on the one he wants to be his master. Guilt When characters fail, they must deal with the consequences. Feelings of frustration, anguish, and guilt drive many to attempt to correct or atone for their mistakes. Villains motivated by guilt might have made an immoral choice, failed a loved one, or set in motion a series of events that led to disaster. To make up for their part in the outcome, they overcom- pensate and try to fi x whatever went wrong, often making the situation worse. Example (Vengeance): When a body- guard failed to stop an assassin because he was drunk in his quarters, he swore off ale and began to brutally attack anyone who he believes played a role in the conspiracy. Hate Whether they hate a person, a country, or a whole race of creatures, villains motivated by hatred are implacable and intolerant, capable of dreadful acts in pursuit of destroying the object of their disgust. They aim to do maximum violence to their hated foes, and they might go so far as to commit mass murder or genocide to achieve their ends. Emmara’s battle champion, he revels in the death and suffering The minotaur dislikes Farror, knowing instinctively that the erinyes is not truly sworn to Emmara. In fact, he views the arrogant devil as a threat to his mistress and to himself. Although Jebrix does not have the intelligence to actively plot against Farror, he does not help the erinyes in battle unless explicitly ordered to do so by Emmara. USING JEBRIX As Emmara’s bodyguard, Jebrix normally stays close by her. If the PCs invade the Soth Tarnel, they almost certainly run afoul of him and the two minotaur guards under his com- mand (see tactical encounter 6–2, page 106). On occasion, however, Jebrix leaves the tower to lead attacks against particularly reviled foes of his mistress. The PCs could encounter him as they guard one such individual. Alternatively, Jebrix and his raging minions could attack the PCs as they camp in the wilderness. Appearance and Behavior Tall and massively muscled, Jebrix looks like a human covered in thick fur, and he has the head of an enormous bull. One of his ears has been chewed off, and his black, almost lifeless eyes gleam with hate. He dyes his fur deep red in homage to his deity, and his jet black +2 full plate is splattered with the dried blood of his victims. Jebrix is a simple, unimaginative creature, overwhelmingly committed to the tenets of Erythnul. He lives to spread the suffering and evil demanded by his lord. The screams of the dying and the hot splash of a foe’s blood on his fur excite him beyond all reason. Jebrix uses his cleric powers to heal his companions as needed or raise them from the dead. These actions are not signs of compassion on his part; rather, he views his fellow minotaurs as vital tools in his mission to spread the dogma of Erythnul throughout the world. He has little need for gold, treasure, or other material goods. The only items he covets are those that help him slaughter the innocent and the helpless. Jebrix exhibits little initiative, preferring to leave strategy to Emmara. Once given orders, however, he follows them with a single-minded purpose that borders on the fanatical. The following areas correspond with those on the map on page 103. 1. Durrin’s Rest: Set at the base of the Soth Tarnel, Durrin’s Rest is a large sea cave that fl oods almost completely at high tide. Low tide, however, reveals a long, low rock shelf covered in seaweed. The water has eroded the shelf, making its surface uneven. Two worn, seaweed-wrapped statues of humans wearing plate armor and carrying greatswords fl ank a broad staircase (area 2). Ceremonial Landing: The Stair Martial is interrupted in three places by fl at landings; these feature intricate carv- ings of human warriors battling a host of orcs. Small alcoves with seats carved into the wall were meant to give mourners a place to rest before continuing their ascent. Emmara’s elite guards—two barbarian minotaurs led by Jebrix—use the lowest ceremonial landing as a barracks and guard chamber. From here, they watch and listen for signs of trouble from below. Schwalb Art by Wayne England "It is tragic, really. My church, or should I say St. Cuthbert's church of course, seems fraught with those who have no conception of retribution, no understanding of what it means to truly uphold the Scale of Balance. The trouble, my friends, stems from hesitation. Our great land chokes on the Lawbreakers that walk without fear of retribution, without fear of paying the debts they not only owe to their countrymen but to Him, the Judge whose perfect insight and commitment revealed to us the Law. Is it not our duty, our divine command, to seek out these culprits and pay them tenfold for the transgressions against our people, our country, our god? Indeed, it is and each day we falter, each day we allow to pass without meting justice, each second that falls from the hourglass besmirches the name of St. Cuthbert and shames us all. No longer can we wait. No longer will we permit the Lawbreakers to walk unmolested, to shirk their obligation to his perfect Law. No longer shall we be shamed by their wickedness. Take up thy swords and shields and go forth. Visit upon their heads the scourge of St. Cuthbert's wrath and let His anger echo throughout the lands, to send children screaming, women wailing, and unman those who witness the cold justice of our divine command. Go forth and do the work of our master. Level once more the Scales of Balance and free us all from the yoke of corruption..." Lawbringer Hemtose Exemplars of Evil unleashes an assortment of terrifying foes and villains capable of fathomless evil into your games. From an insane goblinoid pirate scouring the seas to find the means to unleash an evil so terrible its mere presence promises doom to the world, to an exiled githyanki lich that plots in the ruins of Moil, spinning through the void of the Negative Energy Plane to visit incredible destruction on the Lich-Queen and her servants, this new sourcebook provides a cast of despicable foes guaranteed to fill your players' hearts with fear and loathing. Of course, many foes exist out there, and not all of them can fit within those soiled pages. So read about a new nonplayer character who gives you a taste of what's to come. While he isn't actually evil, the extreme fervor and zeal with which he upholds his beliefs is such that he may end up in conflict with the player characters in your game. Lawbringer Hemtose "I would be lying if I said I was completely comfortable with Lawbringer Hemtose's zeal. I cannot fault him for his earnestness and dedication to his faith, but his methods leave much to be desired. And then there is the matter of his politicking: It makes me wonder if the just Lawbringer wishes more than to uphold the Law about which he so fervently preaches." -- Jessica Casten of the Billets While clearly a villain, Lawbringer Hemtose does not see himself as such and in fact regards himself as one of St. Cuthbert's most constant followers -- a champion cut from the same cloth as the Judge who first set down the Law. What makes Hemtose a villain, though, is the zeal with which he pursues justice. It's common knowledge that followers of the god of retribution are anything but subtle when chasing down Lawbreakers, who are enemies denounced by the church of St. Cuthbert. Father Hemtose, however, seems willing to go to any Lawbringer Hemtose length to hunt these fugitives down, even stooping as low as to employ assassins, thugs, and, some whisper, monsters. He adheres to a higher understanding of the Law, peering through the word to arrive at the Law's intent, and so long as the Law is upheld and balance restored, it matters not what methods he uses to bring his enemies to justice. Background Lawbringer Hemtose is the second son of a minor lord and cursed with a healthy older brother. He stood little chance of attaining his father's titles and was less likely to inherit any kind of substantial fortune. So, as was the custom in his land, he left his father's holdfast for the clergy after languishing in his father's court for a time. There he found acceptance in the militant halls of a St. Cuthbert abbey. Always a clever lad and blessed with many talents, he maneuvered into the upper echelons of the temple, gaining the ear of the abbot himself and enjoying more luxuries than ordinarily afforded to his peers. During one of the long evenings that Hemtose spent in the company of his mentor, the abbot told him worriedly about the Stars, a fringe group of priests who worked to root out corruption from within the ranks of the extant clergy. Hemtose knew the abbot had unusual tastes and, in the privacy of his inner sanctum, his mentor indulged in things that were clearly out of the bounds of what the church deemed acceptable. Sensing an opportunity to escape the drudgery of his home, Hemtose secretly contacted an Inquisitor of the Stars and revealed his mentor's excesses in graphic detail, embellishing where necessary. Not long after, the abbot disappeared and Hemtose found his standing within the church much improved. For the next few years, Hemtose used his cunning, his political clout, and his extensive understanding of the intricacies of the Law to climb the ranks of the church until he attained an important position in the court of a powerful duke. As the noble's principle advisor and confidant, Hemtose has become an insidious force in the land, spreading his presence like an inky stain. No town -- no hamlet -- is safe from his eyes and ears for his spies are everywhere, always watching, always listening for anything incriminating to pass along to their powerful master. Goals Hemtose is driven to enforce the Law, to ensure the balance is maintained and to punish transgressors of that Law properly. He uses whatever means are necessary, even if he must dirty his hands and those of his close servants to do so. He's not above spying or hiring unsavory mercenaries and savage monsters to bring his enemies to justice. He does what the situation demands and thinks nothing of bending or changing the rules to suit his needs. Hemtose's obsession with law stems directly from his hunger of power. For as long as he can remember, he has always resented the station his brother inherited and rued his own useless life as the second son of a minor lordling. This resentment blossomed into lust for that which he could not have and so he turned his considerable talents to finding some way to achieve what was denied to him. The church is the vehicle of his goals. It justifies his every action and through a show of piety and service, his status improves. Each heretic dragged back to his dungeons and put to the question is another opportunity at advancement. Those who confess their crimes nudge Hemtose one step farther, granting him fame, notoriety, and above all, influence. Using This Villain Lawbringer Hemtose offers an interesting adversary for your player characters in that he's not evil and, in all likelihood, he's well-insulated from their reprisals by a monolithic church. As adventurers, the PCs are bound to cross Hemtose at some point in their careers, perhaps as a result of plundering a particular dungeon that Lawbringer Hemtose interests the priest or by eliminating one of Hemtose's servants who simply followed the Lawbringer's orders. When they do, they gain the anger and enmity of this powerful cleric, and their lives suddenly become quite complicated. Hemtose is not one to seek out and destroy the PCs himself; he lacks the raw offensive abilities to wipe out a competent party of adventurers. Instead, Hemtose is a master of manipulation. A skilled orator, he can whip a crowd into a frenzy and convert the most dastardly people to his cause with but a few fiery words inspired by the gospel of his faith. No, Hemtose has no interest in hunting down PCs himself. He has minions for that sort of work. Upon gaining the Lawbringer's attention, the PCs are unlikely to lose it. Once Hemtose identifies a heretic (real or imagined), he's loathe to abandon him. He uses everything in his arsenal to bring the characters to justice. There's no place far enough removed that Hemtose's agents can't find them, no dungeon deep enough, no redoubt remote enough to put off his dogs. The characters will likely have to face his servants repeatedly until they can find some way to discredit the cleric and remove him from power. In the interim, they face pursuit even unto the ends of the earth. Hemtose in Faerûn In the Forgotten Realms, Hemtose is a cleric of Hoar, the Doombringer and Lord of Three Thunders. Hemtose is more concerned with revenge and retribution, and though he retains his place in the court of a powerful noble, he is far more obsessed with responding to slights and visiting vengeance on anyone who crosses him. Exchange the Destruction domain for the Retribution domain (SC p279). Hemtose in Eberron As a cleric of the Sovereign Host, Hemtose acknowledges all of the gods that make up this church, but he secretly cleaves closest to Aureon, the Sovereign of Law and Lore. As a subscriber to the classical texts that define the schism as a result of a moral divide, Hemtose finds that the new theories bubbling up that suggest the conflict instead falls along lines of civilization and the wild drive him to distraction. Hemtose desperately works to assert the letter of law as he sees it and stamps out these heretical factions before their influence can undermine the good work of his church. Appearance and Behavior Standing just over 6 feet tall with a thick build and chiseled features, Hemtose, in spite of his advancing age, still cuts an impressive figure. His good looks and powerful personality make it a challenge to refute his well- reasoned arguments. Hemtose prefers to wear the full vestments of his order wherever he goes, so that he can stand as the embodiment of all of his patron deity's ideals. In person, Hemtose is forceful, direct, and to the point. He's not one to mince words, preferring to lay out his position clearly and support his views with complex theological arguments drawn from the Law and other religious texts, some of which he himself penned. Although some might be put off by his aggressive style, he has a knack for stoking the fires of passion in those he meets and even those who disagree with his position find themselves helpless to argue against him. Behind the scenes, Hemtose is a looming spectre and a force of calculated destruction. He issues orders and his minions follow them to the letter. His soldiers scour the countryside, sweeping through communities large and small in search of those Hemtose has deemed to be lawbreakers -- whether they truly are or not. As his power grows, so too does the fear his very name evokes. description: Hemtose and all allies within 30 feet gain a +4 sacred bonus on Will saves. Using this ability is a Lawbringer Hemtose full-round action and lasts as long as Hemtose speaks (concentrates) and for 3 rounds thereafter. Inspire hope is a mind-affecting ability. Fast Talk (Ex) Hemtose may make a rushed Diplomacy check as a full-round action at only a -5 penalty. Skill Mastery (Ex) When making a Diplomacy or Intimidate check, Hemtose may always take 10 even if stress and distractions would normally prevent him from doing so. Hook "Retribution requires revenge." Albrik Blount "In doing the Judge's work, one must not dwell overlong on the outward appearance and manners of those who hear the call to serve. If my long years have taught me anything, it's that appearances can be deceiving." -- Lawbringer Hemtose Half-ogres, by their nature, are not prone to finding much use for St. Cuthbert or his followers, and many, like Lawbringer Hemtose their giant parents, delight in the chance to pull these self-righteous prudes apart. So, many wonder how it is that the ogre-blooded Albrik Blount found his way not only in the church of the Judge, but did so as a Lawbringer's personal brute. Few half-ogres find their childhoods pleasant and Albrik Blount is no exception. The unwanted spawn of an ill- advised tryst, he was left at an orphanage run by clerics of St. Cuthbert as a squalling babe. As he grew, he became a bully and an absolute terror in the home, driving the abbess to take steps to contain the wickedness in his heart and guide him onto the true path of righteousness. The abbess devoted herself to his upbringing, cloistering him away from the other children for his and their protection, but despite her best efforts, the weight of corruption weighed heavily upon him. Desperate, she took the ungainly youth to meet with Lawbringer Hemtose in the hopes that the great man would reveal the truth and wisdom of St. Cuthbert into the small and vicious mind of her lowly charge. The results were miraculous. Hemtose seemed to light up when he examined the young half-ogre, and he offered to take charge of the boy's remaining years, something to which the abbess readily agreed (no doubt with some relief). Hemtose used every talent he had learned to winnow away the taint in the half-ogre lad, stripping him of his natural inclinations in an effort to find that kernel of humanity he knew existed somewhere within him. He subjected Albrik to his most moving speeches, enlightened him on the finer points of dogma, and gave him over to the best martial instructors the church had to offer to instill discipline and fighting prowess. In the end, he succeeded and Albrik became one of Hemtose's greatest allies. Goals Albrik's transformation was profound. Suppressed were his wicked impulses and his destructive behavior. A constant and abiding devotion to the Law and the grace of the Judge replaced them. His piety is the foundation on which he has built his life, and he has no goal -- no desire -- beyond simple service to his god, and, by extension, the voice of his god: Lawbringer Hemtose. Albrik's deepest desire is to purge himself of his ogre blood and to become fully human. This secret hope consumes his dreams, and he's ever after some easy path to kill his dark half and allow the light of his human blood to shine brightly. Should he ever learn of such a process, he might even set aside his service to Hemtose to escape the shackles of his existence. Using Albrik Blount Simply put, Albrik is Hemtose's hammer. There's nothing delicate about this minion. He does as ordered, leads forces of church warriors and other, less savory, foot soldiers on whatever crusade his master demands. Albrik has come a long way from his brutish past, but he always finds himself sliding toward his father's wickedness -- a fact that reveals itself in the pulped and bloody captives he brings back to Hemtose's dungeons. These lapses have led to frequent losses of his paladin abilities and a quick trek back to the church to find a ranking priest who can atone him of his misdeeds. Appearance and Behavior Albrik Blount is a hulking warrior encased in black enameled half-plate armor. A massive demon-faced helmet conceals his brutish, almost-human features. Standing nearly 9-feet tall and weighing over 400 pounds, he's a terror on the battlefield, but also a font of courage to his allies. Blount never uses a horse in battle since he can't find one big enough to ride and so instead he charges into the thick of his enemies swinging his razor-sharp greataxe, sending chunks of his foes flying in all directions. Lawbringer Hemtose A fierce warrior indeed, Blount is more complicated than his appearance and bearing would otherwise suggest. Behind his grim façade is a conflicted soul -- a being divided by the filthy impulses of his tainted blood and the ethical instruction imposed on him by his master. This division manifests most often in combat, when he loses control for brief spells, or when interrogating a prisoner, which is just too awful to describe. However, when not waging war or rooting out heretics, he's prone to sullen melancholia, dark moods, and pessimistic reflection, making him most unpleasant company under the best circumstances. If the charge attack misses, the smite ability is not consider to be used. This ability replaces the paladin's special mount class feature. A DC 16 Fortitude save negates this effect. Justice Blade (Chaos) (Su) Albrik may spend a daily use of smite evil to instead smite chaos. This ability works exactly like smite evil, except that it affects chaotic targets. Sacrament of Trust Albrik has a great deal more freedom to act on behalf of St. Cuthbert than do other Lawbringer Hemtose paladins of the god of vengeance. Whenever Albrik seeks to atone for deeds he willingly committed in the name of his faith but that broke his code of conduct, a cleric casting an atonement spell on his behalf does not expend 500 XP as is normally required. This reprieve applies only to acts intended to further the cause of his church. Hook "I do good?"
